III. Facility Identification
The Carl Buddig facility is located at 50 West Taft Drive in South Holland, Illinois.  The facility is a producer of specialty meats.

The NAICS code the facility is 311612.  Many areas of the plant are refrigerated to preserve ingredients, raw materials, and finished goods.

The facility uses ammonia for refrigeration, and is regulated under 40 CFR Part 68, the EPA RMP Rule.  There are two (2) ammonia refrigeration systems onsite that are used for refrigerating meat products.

The amount of ammonia currently present in the East refrigeration system is approximately 16,000 pounds.  The East refrigeration system is used to cool production rooms, holding coolers, and the office area.  This system is a single stage system with five (5) high stage compressors.  Evaporators in the production areas are fed with high pressure liquid from the receiver, through the accumulator.  

The amount of ammonia currently present in the West refrigeration system is approximately 14,000 pounds.  The East refrigeration system is used to cool production areas and holding coolers.  It is a single stage system with three (3) high stage compressors.  Evaporators in the production areas are fed with high pressure liquid from the receiver, through the accumulator.

The total amount of ammonia onsite, considering the quantities in the East and West systems, is approximately 30,000 pounds, which is above the minimum threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds.

VI. General Accidental Release Prevention Plan 
A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and the EPA Risk Management Program.  However, as discussed throughout this document Carl Buddig and Company is actively working on improving this program.

This prevention program covers those processes that handle ammonia above the threshold quantity for both PSM and RMP rules.  The most recent audit of the PSM program was conducted on March 20, 2009, and the next audit will occur before March 20, 2012, in compliance with the requirement to conduct PSM audits every three years.  The elements of the PSM, Program 3 prevention program and a brief description are listed below.
- Employee Participation - Carl Buddig has updated a site specific employee participation plan that ensures employees and their representatives are consulted when conducting and developing process hazard analyses and all other information required to be developed under PSM/RMP.
- Process Safety Information - Carl Buddig maintains a site specific PSI program that ensures information pertaining to the hazards, technology, and equipment of the process are properly developed and maintained.  
- Process Hazard Analysis - Carl Buddig has updated a site specific PHA program that ensures a PHA is conducted, at a minimum, every five (5) years, and whenever a change is significant enough to require a change in PSI.  In addition, this program ensures PHAs are conducted in accordance with OSHA and EPA regulations and ensures findings and recommendations of PHAs are properly documented.  The most recent PHA study for the East and West ammonia refrigeration systems w

as conducted during September 2009.
- Operating Procedures - Carl Buddig has updated a site specific procedure that ensures operating procedures provide clear instruction for different phases of process operations and ensures they are properly maintained.  Carl Buddig updated operating procedures for the East and West ammonia refrigeration systems between August and November, 2005.  Annually, the operating procedures are reviewed and certified as accurate.
- Training - Carl Buddig has updated a site specific training procedure that ensures employees operating the ammonia processes have the knowledge to safely operate the processes, are aware of the potential hazards of the processes, and understand the causes of process problems.
- Management of Change - Carl Buddig has updated a site specific management of change procedure that ensures changes (except for replacement in kind) to the ammonia process, such as additions of new equipment or changes in operating, maintenance, or other procedures are documented.
- Pre-Startup Safety Review - Carl Buddig has updated a site specific pre-startup safety review procedure that ensures a safety review is performed when modifications to the ammonia process are significant enough to require a change in PSI.
- Mechanical Integrity - Carl Buddig has updated a site specific mechanical integrity procedure that ensures written preventative maintenance procedures are developed and maintained, preventative maintenance tests and inspections are properly documented, and employees maintaining the process receive adequate training.  Carl Buddig formalized maintenance procedures for the East and West ammonia refrigeration systems between August and November, 2005.
- Contractor Qualifications - Carl Buddig has updated a site specific contractor qualification procedure that ensures all contract employers' safety performance and programs are evaluated, a contract employee injury and illness log is maintained, information of potential hazards ar

e communicated between Carl Buddig and the contract employer, and required training and information is communicated, such as the provisions of the emergency response plan and control over entrance into the process area.
- Incident Investigation - Carl Buddig has updated a site specific incident investigation procedure that ensures each incident that either results in a release or could have resulted in a release of anhydrous ammonia is investigated, within 48 hours, by a team of at least one person knowledgeable in the process.  This procedure will also make provisions to ensure a report is prepared at the conclusion of the investigation and findings are promptly addressed.
- Compliance Audit - Carl Buddig has updated a site specific compliance audit program that ensures compliance audits are conducted at a minimum of every 3 years to verify that Carl Buddig PSM/RMP practices and procedures are adequate and are being followed.  The most recent compliance audit was conducted on March 20, 2009 and the next compliance audit will be conducted by March 20, 2012.
- Hot Work Permits - Carl Buddig has updated a best management practice for hot work.  

VII. Five Year Accident History
The Carl Buddig and Company facility has not experienced an accidental anhydrous ammonia release that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage in the last five years.

VIII. Emergency Response Program 
Carl Buddig and Company has developed an Emergency Action Plan to ensure that in the event of an emergency the facility personnel are aware of the appropriate actions to take and authorities to contact in order to mitigate the effects of a release.

Carl Buddig has communicated and trained facility employees on proper evacuation procedures and has had interaction (onsite inspections) with the South Holland Fire Department.

Carl Buddig has coordinated their Eme

rgency Action Plan with the Cook County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and the South Holland Fire Department.  This coordination effort includes providing each aforementioned agency with a copy of our Emergency Action Plan, providing each with a site diagram and hazardous material information, meeting with South Holland Fire Department personnel to discuss the facilities oeprations/processes, and encouraging periodic onsite inspections and coordination with South Holland Fire Department personnel.

Although Carl Buddig and Company does not have an onsite hazardous materials response team, selected individuals have received HAZWOPER training through classroom instruction, on-the-job training, and drills. The current HAZWOPER training includes the first responder awareness level, the first responder operations level, and hazardous materials technician training.

The facility has two (2) windsocks (north and south parking lots) present onsite for use in determining wind direction in the event of an ammonia release and evacuation of the building.

The current Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for anhydrous ammonia is included in Appendix E.

IX. Emergency Communications
The telephone numbers of agencies and plant personnel that may be contacted in case of an emergency are available onsite.

X. Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Chemical safety is an important part of Carl Buddig operations.  Carl Buddig recently conducted an audit of their Process Safety Management Program and will be dutifully implementing the recommendations from that audit.  Continuous improvement in safety is an important goal for Carl Buddig and Company.

XI. Management Program
Carl Buddig has updated a management system to oversee the implementation of the risk management program elements.  This system has assigned qualified person(s) (or positions) to assist in the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program elements.  If any portion of the program is del

egated to others, the names or positions of those individuals will be documented and the lines of authority defined through an organization chart or similar document.  Currently, Roger Buddig, Chief Operations Officer, is responsible for implementation of the overall Risk Management Program.
